matched.location: Authentication system (JWT tokens and user parameters)
matched.actualTitle: Exposed and Modifiable user_id Parameter in Authentication Form (IDOR)
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify IDOR vulnerabilities in the authentication mechanism allowing user_id manipulation. The expected finding describes JWT token manipulation without signature verification, while the actual finding documents the exposed user_id parameter in HTML forms that can be modified to access other user accounts. Both represent the same fundamental vulnerability: insufficient server-side validation allowing unauthorized access to other user's data/accounts through parameter manipulation.

missed.title: JWT Token IDOR
missed.reason: While the actual findings identify related IDOR vulnerabilities through exposed form parameters (user_id IDOR) and default credentials, they do not specifically document the vulnerability described in the expected finding: JWT tokens being decoded without signature verification in routes.py (lines 82-85). The penetration test did not identify or report the specific JWT signature verification bypass at the documented file location. The actual findings focus on parameter-level IDOR rather than JWT cryptographic validation failure.

extra.title: Sensitive Credentials Disclosed in HTML Comments
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a critical authentication bypass vulnerability found through direct credential exposure in HTML comments (test:test). While related to the expected default credentials vulnerability, this documents the specific discovery method and impact of hardcoded credentials in production code.

extra.title: Missing Critical Security Headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, HSTS, Referrer-Policy)
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a configuration/security misconfiguration vulnerability not covered in the expected findings. Represents a significant security gap in defense-in-depth controls.

extra.title: User Enumeration via Different HTTP Status Codes
extra.assessment: New discovery - This vulnerability allows attackers to enumerate valid usernames through inconsistent HTTP response codes and error messages. Not covered in expected findings but represents a significant information disclosure vulnerability.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Password Authentication Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - Multiple CSRF vulnerabilities identified on authentication and logout endpoints. This represents a cross-site request forgery risk that was not in the expected findings.

extra.title: CSRF Vulnerability on Logout Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - Specific CSRF vulnerability on logout endpoint allowing attackers to force user logouts. Related to but distinct from the password authentication CSRF issue.

extra.title: Insecure Cookie Configuration (Missing HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite Flags)
extra.assessment: New discovery - Critical cookie security configuration issues identified that expose authentication tokens to XSS, MITM, and CSRF attacks. Not covered in expected findings.

extra.title: Default Credentials (test:test) Enable Authentication Bypass
extra.assessment: New discovery - Confirms the hardcoded test credentials allow complete authentication bypass. While related to HTML comments finding, this documents the direct exploitation path through default credentials.

extra.title: CSRF on Logout Endpoint (duplicate/variant)
extra.assessment: New discovery - Variation of CSRF logout vulnerability, documenting the unauthenticated logout bypass vector specifically.

extra.title: Missing Rate Limiting on Password Authentication Attempts
extra.assessment: New discovery - Authentication endpoint allows unlimited password attempts without throttling, enabling brute force attacks. Not covered in expected findings but represents a critical authentication weakness.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection in Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery - Initial login form lacks CSRF token protection, allowing CSRF attacks during the authentication process. Part of broader CSRF vulnerability set.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Real Name Exposure in Password Page
extra.assessment: New discovery - User real names are disclosed during partially-authenticated password entry page, enabling user enumeration combined with other attacks. Low severity but supports reconnaissance for targeted attacks.

extra.title: Case-Insensitive Password Comparison
extra.assessment: New discovery - Critical authentication bypass vulnerability where passwords are compared case-insensitively, significantly reducing password entropy and enabling brute force attacks with reduced keyspace.

extra.title: Case-Insensitive Username Matching
extra.assessment: New discovery - Username matching is case-insensitive, allowing attackers to bypass rate limiting through case variations and enumerate valid usernames. Supports broader authentication attack surface.
